claim: Double jeopardy means a person cannot be tried twice for the same crime

supporting.text: The principle of double jeopardy is enshrined in the Fifth Amendment of the U.S. Constitution, which explicitly prohibits trying a person twice for the same offense.

attacks.text: The principle of double jeopardy is enshrined in the Fifth Amendment of the U.S. Constitution, which explicitly prohibits trying a person twice for the same offense.
Double jeopardy protections do not apply if the same conduct violates laws of different sovereigns, such as state and federal laws.
The 'dual sovereignty' doctrine is controversial and some legal scholars argue it undermines the original intent of double jeopardy protections.
Double jeopardy only applies after a case reaches final judgment - mistrials or hung juries don't trigger the protection.
Civil trials can proceed after criminal acquittals for the same conduct, as they are considered different 'offenses' legally.

supporting.text: Legal systems in many countries, including the U.S. and U.K., recognize double jeopardy as a fundamental protection against government overreach and harassment of defendants.

attacks.text: Legal systems in many countries, including the U.S. and U.K., recognize double jeopardy as a fundamental protection against government overreach and harassment of defendants.
Double jeopardy protections do not apply if new evidence emerges that was not available in the original trial.
Some legal systems allow retrials for the same crime if the first trial was deemed a mistrial or resulted in a hung jury.
International courts or different sovereign states may prosecute the same crime separately, bypassing double jeopardy protections.
The exception for new evidence is rare and requires extremely compelling proof to override double jeopardy protections.
Mistrials and hung juries are procedural exceptions, not contradictions to the principle of double jeopardy in finalized cases.
Separate prosecutions by different sovereigns are a legal gray area and not a direct challenge to domestic double jeopardy principles.

supporting.text: Supreme Court rulings, such as in 'Blockburger v. United States' (1932), have upheld the double jeopardy clause, defining 'same offense' for legal purposes.

attacks.text: Supreme Court rulings, such as in 'Blockburger v. United States' (1932), have upheld the double jeopardy clause, defining 'same offense' for legal purposes.
The 'Blockburger' test has exceptions, such as when crimes involve separate sovereigns (e.g., state and federal prosecutions for the same act).
The Supreme Court's interpretation of 'same offense' has evolved, with later cases like 'Grady v. Corbin' (1990) introducing conflicting standards before being overturned.
The 'dual sovereignty' doctrine is controversial and criticized for undermining the spirit of double jeopardy by allowing multiple prosecutions for the same conduct.
Despite fluctuations, the core principle of 'Blockburger' remains controlling precedent, reaffirmed in cases like 'United States v. Dixon' (1993).

supporting.text: Double jeopardy prevents the state from repeatedly prosecuting an individual until it secures a conviction, ensuring fairness in the judicial process.

attacks.text: Double jeopardy prevents the state from repeatedly prosecuting an individual until it secures a conviction, ensuring fairness in the judicial process.

Most legal systems have strict limitations on reopening cases with new evidence to prevent abuse.

supporting.text: International human rights instruments, like the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights (Article 14(7)), also prohibit double jeopardy, reflecting its global acceptance.

attacks.text: International human rights instruments, like the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights (Article 14(7)), also prohibit double jeopardy, reflecting its global acceptance.

Article 14(7) of the ICCPR allows states to make reservations, meaning some countries may not fully adhere to the double jeopardy prohibition.
Most states that ratified the ICCPR did so without reservations on Article 14(7), preserving its core principle in practice.
